response.answer_text: I can understand you are using a samsung mobile or this question you asked is you saw this somewhere in a samsung device And i think you saw this in the device usage history page of your google account The meaning of com.samsung.android.incallui is the interface which you see when you are taking a call which has functions like loud speaker, mute and reject etc. Basically the naming system of an app can be like this Com.Company name.android. Appname This applies to all apps and you can easily guess what that weird text means

It’s an X.500 - Wikipedia directory serivces naming convention to put the components, dot separated, from most general to most specific. The DNS ended up going backwards from that, because it was felt the site name was most important. Realize that at the time, there were only 4 TLDs (Top Level Domains): COM, EDU, NET, and MIL, so going in reverse from X,500 made sense. LDAP is in fact derived from X.500, including the use of BER and DER encoding. In any event, it indicates and “:android” component, from “samsung.com” called “incallui”. Or “in call ui”. It’s the component that provides the UI you see when you are actively in a telephone call: keypad, speaker button, mute button, hang up button, and so forth.
